column4: white-space:pre-wrap"">It is just a regular box, to open it, you cut the tape on the side, and pour out three separate bags. The box art depicts the Hulkbuster taking on some AIM agents. Not much else to say here.

white-space:pre-wrap""><span style=""font-style:normal"">Upon opening bag one, I was delighted to see it contained Rescue, the figure I was most looking forward to in this set. Bag one has you build the complete body of the Hulkbuster and Rescue&#39

column4: white-space:pre-wrap""><span style=""font-style:normal"">The final model has a nice combination of light and dark red, with gold accents. It stands taller and sits wider than all previous Hulk (and War Machine) busters except for obviously the &quot
column6: one. There is room for Iron Man to sit in the body of the set, you lift the rather flat looking head, and place him in. There is a small control panel piece that uses a sticker inside
column7: it looks nice. Rescue and her laser shooter can sit on either shoulder of the set, with weak connection. The back of the set is rather detailed and has clips for the two power bursts included in bag one. The ankles have minimum articulation, while there is none on the knees. The waist can spin 360 degrees, and is fun to position as if it is winding up for a punch or a kick. The arm joints are what you would expect, decent articulation on the shoulders and elbows. The shoulder armor was really enjoyable to build, and looks great.

column4: white-space:pre-wrap"">This set is a great Hulkbuster out of all the play scale ones, flat head and all. Personally, I like the flat head. The minifigures are good, one is great, and they all work in the set. The shoulder laser mount may be a bit useless (my younger brother loves it though) but that is minor, and you can always take it off. In the end, I would recommend this set to anyone without a Hulkbuster, or with. It is just an all-around good set!
